subject: WebObjects
msgSnippet: Is anyone using junit with WebObjects?  If so, how are you kicking off your applications? In order to get access to the models/DB, an application must get
messageBody:
Is anyone using junit with WebObjects? If so, how are you kicking off your
applications?

In order to get access to the models/DB, an application must get kicked off.
Where are you calling the TestRunner/AllTests suite code? (From Main,
Application, .... which method?)

Thanks.
Michael Finney
Sun Certified Programmer for the Java 2 Platform
Sun Certified Developer for the Java 2 Platform


> -----Original Message-----
> From: Randy Cox [SMTP:randy.cox@...]
> Sent: Thursday, February 15, 2001 9:28 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] (unknown)
>
> Herm
>
> Take a look at the TestSetup class. This is a TestDecorator that adds
> setup
> and teardown arround a group of test
>
> From the 3.5 FAQ
>
> How do I run setup code once for all my TestCases?
> Wrap the top level suite in a subclass of TestSetup. Here is a sample
> AllTests.suite() method:
>
>
> public static Test suite() {
> TestSuite suite= new TestSuite();
> ...add your tests and suites here...
> TestSetup wrapper= new TestSetup(suite) {
> public void setUp() {
> oneTimeSetUp();
> }
> };
> return wrapper;
> }
>
> I hope this helps
>
> Randy Cox
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Herm Greider
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Thursday, February 15, 2001 8:13 AM
> Subject: [junit] (unknown)
>
>
> Testing JDBC code question:
>
> I am currently doing inserts for database test
> data in a setup() method. This is getting rather
> slow to run because it runs for each test (duh).
>
> In general, for testing JDBC code, is it more useful
> to define test data in a separate SQL file that
> I run beforehand? I would prefer to be able to do it
> in code to make sure it's refreshed correctly before
> I run (I'll forget to run the separate SQL). But, I
> really want to be able to define it once for a group
> of tests because they all use the same data (and
> don't do any updates to cause side-effects).
>
> Would it be reasonable to do something like this in
> a constructor for the group of tests or is that taboo
> because it links TestCases together?
>
> Thanks,
> Herm Greider
> Lexis-Nexis
> Dayton, Ohio
>
